facts.title: The 'Oil of Vitriol' Nickname
facts.description: Historically, sulfuric acid was called 'oil of vitriol' because it was made by heating metal sulfates like iron sulfate. Medieval alchemists thought the name sounded cool.

facts.title: It’s Thirsty as Heck
facts.description: Sulfuric acid is highly hygroscopic, meaning it aggressively absorbs water from everything—even the air. It can dehydrate sugar into a foamy tower of carbon.

facts.title: Burns Without a Flame
facts.description: Sulfuric acid doesn’t need fire to cause damage. When it contacts skin or cloth, it reacts with water so violently that it causes severe chemical burns.

facts.title: Venus’s Favorite Juice
facts.description: The clouds on Venus contain sulfuric acid droplets. If you ever visit (you won’t), an umbrella wouldn’t help—it would just dissolve.

facts.title: A Smelly Origin Story
facts.description: Sulfuric acid’s discovery links back to burning sulfur, which smells like rotten eggs. Ancient chemists probably thought, 'Let’s make something useful out of this!'

facts.title: King of Chemicals
facts.description: Sulfuric acid is called the 'King of Chemicals' because of its vast industrial applications, from fertilizers to petroleum refining.

facts.title: Used in Cleaning Metals
facts.description: It is used in metal processing to remove rust and oxidation from iron and steel, making surfaces cleaner and more reactive for further treatment.

facts.title: Vital for Paper Industry
facts.description: Sulfuric acid plays a role in breaking down wood fibers during the paper-making process, making it an essential part of the industry.

facts.title: Naturally Occurs in Acid Rain
facts.description: Small amounts of sulfuric acid form in the atmosphere due to sulfur dioxide emissions, contributing to acid rain and environmental damage.

facts.title: Battery Acid
facts.description: Sulfuric acid is the key ingredient in lead-acid batteries used in vehicles and backup power systems, making it crucial for energy storage.

faqs.question: What is the Contact Process?
faqs.answer: The Contact Process is an industrial method for producing sulfuric acid. It involves the catalytic oxidation of sulfur dioxide (SO₂) to sulfur trioxide (SO₃), which is then absorbed in water to form H₂SO₄. It’s widely used because it’s efficient and produces high-purity acid

faqs.question: Why is it called the Contact Process?
faqs.answer: The name comes from the “contact” between the reactant gases (SO₂ and O₂) and the solid catalyst surface, where the reaction occurs.

faqs.question: How does pressure affect the Contact Process?
faqs.answer: Even though higher pressure favors SO₃ production, only 2 atm is used because higher pressures would make the process too expensive.

faqs.question: Why is sulfuric acid important in car batteries?
faqs.answer: It’s the key electrolyte in lead-acid batteries, allowing the flow of electric charge. Without it, your car wouldn’t start on a cold morning!

faqs.question: How pure is Contact Process sulfuric acid for space?
faqs.answer: 99.9% pure H₂SO₄—perfect for space mission batteries Ultra-pure H₂SO₄, made with advanced purification, is used in rocket fuel and satellite components due to its reliability

faqs.question: What happens if you add water to concentrated sulfuric acid?
faqs.answer: BOOM! The reaction is highly exothermic (heat-releasing), and can cause splattering or even explosions. Instead, always add acid to water, never the other way around!

faqs.question: Why do Venus’s clouds contain sulfuric acid?
faqs.answer: The planet's atmosphere has a lot of sulfur dioxide, which reacts with sunlight and oxygen to form sulfuric acid droplets. If you ever visit (which you won’t), an umbrella wouldn’t help—it would just dissolve!

faqs.question: What happens if the Contact Process is done at very high temperatures?
faqs.answer: The reaction is exothermic, so too much heat actually reduces the yield by shifting equilibrium backward
